items.synopsis: Local stocks have pulled back from early gains. The RBA's assistant governor of economics will join Westpac as chief economist. US jobs numbers were below forecasts but wages growth was stronger. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX loses steam, Luci Ellis to leave RBA for Westpac, mixed messages on US jobs market

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: After opening higher and losing steam through the session, the Australian share market has finished in the red on Monday — so much for a strong start after last week's poor showing! Mining stocks weighed from mid-session as iron ore futures turned negative — BHP (-1.1%), Rio Tinto (-1.1%) and Fortescue (-2pc) all went from gains to losses. And the major banks also ended in the red, giving up early gains, while gold miners remained a bright spot. By the close of trade, all sectors were lower, except for education and industrials. The biggest moves on the benchmark index were: Bottom 5 Imugene: -4.3% Tabcorp: -3.6% South32: -2.7% Magellan Financial: -2.7% A2 Milk: -2.3% Top 5: Bellevue Gold: +5.1% Monadelphous: +4% De Grey Mining: +3.4% Regis Resources: +3.1% Silver Lake Resources: +3.1% The Aussie dollar also pulled back, after economic data out of China raised concerns about its post-COVID recovery. Join us on the markets blog bright and early tomorrow for all the overnight market action, plus some local news out mid-morning in the form of Westpac consumer confidence and the NAB business survey. In the meantime, you can watch The Business at 8:45pm AEST on the ABC News Channel or anytime on iView — tonight the show will look at calls for tougher regulation on businesses abusing their market power, the economic challenges facing China and what's ahead for US earnings season. Until next time!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX reverses course to close in the red

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Australian Bureau of Statistics has released its monthly business turnover figures for May, and it shows turnover increasing in 11 of the 13 industries. Mining was not one of them. “Mining turnover fell 6 per cent in May, following a 12.1 per cent fall in April, as demand and prices for commodities such as iron ore and coal come off recent highs," ABS head of business indicators Robert Ewing said. The other sector which saw a fall in turnover was food and accommodation services. We've heard a lot about post-COVID 'revenge spending', with people still forking out on dining and travel even as cost of living pressures mount, after several lockdown-disrupted years. However, accommodation and food services saw an 0.3 per cent decline in turnover in the month, after rising for three months. The biggest increase was in electricity, gas, water and waste services, after turnover in that industry fell in April.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Business turnover drops in mining, accommodation & food

children.content: The Australian Bureau of Statistics has released its monthly business turnover figures for May, and it shows turnover increasing in 11 of the 13 industries.
Mining was not one of them.

“Mining turnover fell 6 per cent in May, following a 12.1 per cent fall in April, as demand and prices for commodities such as iron ore and coal come off recent highs," ABS head of business indicators Robert Ewing said.
The other sector which saw a fall in turnover was food and accommodation services.
We've heard a lot about post-COVID 'revenge spending', with people still forking out on dining and travel even as cost of living pressures mount, after several lockdown-disrupted years.
However, accommodation and food services saw an 0.3 per cent decline in turnover in the month, after rising for three months.
The biggest increase was in electricity, gas, water and waste services, after turnover in that industry fell in April.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The local share market has given up some of its early gains and is just modestly higher around lunchtime. Energy stocks remain the standout, while the major miners are now mixed, with Rio Tinto shares slipping into the red. Here are the biggest percentage moves on the ASX 200: Top 5 Monadelphous Group: +4.7% Bellevue Gold: +3.6% Silver Lake Resources: +3.3% Regis Resources: +3.1% Block: +3.1% Bottom 5 Tabcorp: -3.4% Magellan Financial: -3.1% Cromwell Property: -1.8% Transurban: -1.6% Atlas Arteria: -1.5% Around the region, Asian markets are mixed with gains in Hong Kong, Shanghai and Seoul, while stocks in Tokyo have fallen. It follows some weaker-than-expected economic data out of China, with consumer prices barely budging from a year earlier.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX losing steam into lunchtime

children.content: The local share market has given up some of its early gains and is just modestly higher around lunchtime.
Energy stocks remain the standout, while the major miners are now mixed, with Rio Tinto shares slipping into the red.
Here are the biggest percentage moves on the ASX 200:
Around the region, Asian markets are mixed with gains in Hong Kong, Shanghai and Seoul, while stocks in Tokyo have fallen.
It follows some weaker-than-expected economic data out of China, with consumer prices barely budging from a year earlier.

image.altText: A young woman with dark brown hair streaked with turquoise smiles softly.

items.synopsis: A rise in the number of young people without a regular GP has health experts concerned it could leave them at higher risk of developing chronic health conditions later in life.

title.children: Zali was quoted up to $1,200 for a consult. Experts say young people are ditching GPs and specialists over cost

image.altText: Nakkiah Lui wearing a brown blazer dress, not smiling, looking at camera

items.synopsis: When you think of a farmer, what image comes to mind? Nakkiah Lui asks that question on her latest podcast First Eat. If you envisioned a white man in an Akubra, you're not alone. Here's why that's an issue and the impact on your dinner plate.

title.children: How the food you eat could be making you sick and what to do about it
